title: Sudden Unilateral Sensorineural Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I woke up one morning about two years ago and couldn't hear much out of my left ear. I also have ringing in that ear, and it's making it very hard to hear my students in the classroom.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset upon waking approximately 2 years ago.
problem_summary.course: Stable; no improvement with oral or intratympanic steroid treatment.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus in the left ear. No vestibular/balance symptoms reported.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing in the classroom (patient is a teacher) and in social situations.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking improved hearing capabilities for work and social environments.

history.present_illness: Patient reports waking up with decreased hearing in the left ear 2 years ago. Prior to this event, hearing was normal.
history.otologic_history: No history of concerns prior to the sudden loss.
history.medical_psych_history: Treated by an otologist with oral steroids and a series of steroid injections with no perceived improvement.
history.patient_goals: Improve communication ability in noise and classroom settings.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal hearing thresholds (0-10 dB HL). Left ear: Mild-to-moderate SNHL at 250-500 Hz, sloping to severe/profound loss at 750-8000 Hz. No measurable response at 2000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear speech reception and recognition are excellent. Left ear shows a Speech Awareness Threshold (SAT) only, with no ability to recognize words (CNT).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral reflexes present. All other conditions (Left Ipsi, and both Contralateral conditions) are absent.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a profound, steeply sloping sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear (Single-Sided Deafness). Word recognition is excellent in the right ear but unmeasurable in the left. Middle ear function is normal bilaterally.
counseling_points: A conventional hearing aid will not be effective for your left ear because the hearing loss is too severe to provide clarity.
We have two main options to help you hear sounds from your left side: a CROS system or an osseointegrated implant (bone-anchored device).
A CROS system uses a microphone on your bad ear to send sound wirelessly to a hearing aid on your good ear.
An osseointegrated implant vibrates the bone to send sound from the bad side directly to your good inner ear.
Since you are a teacher, being able to hear students on your left side is crucial. We can demonstrate the CROS system today to see if it helps.
notes_for_actor: You are a teacher who relies heavily on hearing for classroom management.
You have lived with this 'dead ear' for 2 years and are frustrated that previous medical treatments didn't work.
You report tinnitus (ringing) in the bad ear.
You are motivated to find a solution but skeptical because the doctors couldn't fix it previously.
